title: Funeral director receives parking ticket while loading coffin
text:
A traffic warden slapped a parking ticket on a hearse as the funeral driver was loading the coffin.

Funeral director Mark Elliott was left fuming after the £70 fixed penalty notice was handed to his black limousine as he prepared to pick up a grieving family.

Funeral director Mark Elliott was handed a £70 fixed penalty notice after he parked on double yellow lines to load a coffin into a hearse near his funeral parlour in

He had left the vehicle on double yellow lines outside his business in Northampton town centre, which he says he has been doing so for three years without any issue.

But he was left stunned when he discovered the fine attached to the windscreen after he finished loading a coffin into a hearse ahead of a funeral service last Friday.

Mr Elliott has now appealed the ticket and vowed to take the matter to court if the fine is not overturned.

He said: 'I thought it was unbelievable. I was speechless. I couldn't put it into words at the time, I was just appalled.

'It's quite clear it's a funeral car. It's black and it says 'funeral service' in the window.

'If the council don't overturn this ticket I'm going to leave a coffin at the council headquarters front doorstep. I'm just that disgusted.

Mr Elliott parked the black limousine (pictured) at The Ridings, behind Mark Elliot Funeral Services on St Giles' Street because it is the only road close and wide enough for the company's procession cars and hearses

Mr Elliott claims The Ridings behind his business is the only street close and wide enough for the company's procession cars and hearses.

He said it is not possible to park in St Giles Street, where the business has been for three years, as it would obstruct traffic

He added: 'I've been parking behind my business for three years when we're getting ready for a funeral and it's never been a problem.

The funeral director said that traffic wardens have always understood the parking issue because the business is a funeral service

'Sometimes I have four limos and hearses here and it's not a problem.

'Traffic wardens have always been okay with it because they see we are a funeral business.'

'The car is left unattended for around five minutes. We park it in a private garage away from the business when it is not in use.

Mr Elliott stood outside his funeral parlour on St Giles' Street holding the £70 fixed penalty fine

'I went straight down to the county council and gave them a piece of my mind.'

Funeral and wedding vehicles can be exempt from parking penalties if they are being used for a service.

Northamptonshire County Council say that because the limousine was 'parked in the Ridings and not outside the funeral parlour', it could not be excused for a ticket.

A spokesperson said: 'Anyone who has received a penalty charge notice can appeal via the normal process.'
description: Funeral director Mark Elliott from Northampton was given a £70 parking ticket while he was loading a coffin onto a hearse in the street behind his business.
